warmup: Can you tell us about the last online course you took—how did you approach your study and what motivated you to complete (or pause) it?
Have you ever paused a course or wanted to review material from the beginning? What typically happens in those situations?

diverge.text: Imagine you have the option to reset your progress in an online course whenever you want, starting again from scratch—what are your initial thoughts about this feature?
diverge.rationale: This question explores user attitudes toward the reset concept, gauges natural reactions, and uncovers perceived value or drawbacks.

diverge.text: Can you describe scenarios where you would (or wouldn’t) want to use a course reset option? What would motivate your choice?
diverge.rationale: This uncovers specific use cases and contexts, helping validate the assumption that learners find this feature relevant and actionable.

diverge.text: How does the idea of a course reset compare to what you’ve seen or used on other learning platforms?
diverge.rationale: This investigates the competitive landscape and whether replay functionality is perceived as a valuable differentiator.

converge: If you had to choose between revisiting old lessons one by one or doing a full course reset, which would you prefer, and why?
How much more likely would you be to repeat a course (for mastery or review) if starting over was just one click away?
Thinking of other platforms you’ve used, would the ability to reset progress make you prefer one over the others? Why or why not?
closure: Is there anything about the course reset feature that would make you hesitate to use it or could cause frustration?
Based on what you’ve heard, how likely would you be to recommend a platform with this feature to a friend or classmate?
What, if anything, feels risky or unclear about the idea of letting users reset their progress? What would you want to know before using it?
